questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and crying while passing urine. She was born at term and has been healthy since. Three months ago, she was treated for a urinary tract infection with oral cefixime. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 144/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 14,000/mm3. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites; urinalysis shows WBCs and gram-negative rods. Urine culture results are pending. Renal ultrasonography shows hydronephrosis of the left kidney. Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated, after which the patient's symptoms improve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injection of bulking agents into the vesicoureteric junction via cystoscopy is a treatment option for children with severe or persistent VUR. However, VUR should first be diagnosed and its severity assessed before surgical or endoscopic repair can be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography (IVP) cannot be used to diagnose VUR since the contrast medium flows in an anterograde direction from the kidney to the bladder.
Image Description:

Excretory urography (AP view; left: pre-contrast; right: 2.5 hours post-contrast)

A calcification medial to the lower pole of the right kidney on the pre-contrast radiograph (red overlay) is shown post-contrast to be an obstructing proximal ureteral calculus (UC; red overlay). The right kidney is enlarged, with persistent enhancement (green overlay). There is pelvicaliectasis and poor contrast-filling of the right ureter (region indicated by dashed lines). The left renal collecting system is normal (purple overlay).

RP: renal pelvis, U: ureter; UB: urinary bladder

C) INCORRECT:

A MAG-3 scan (dynamic renal scintigraphy) is used to distinguish obstructive hydronephrosis from nonobstructive hydronephrosis. However, a different investigation must first be performed to rule out VUR, since VUR is a more common cause of hydronephrosis in children than obstruction. A MAG-3 scan cannot be used to diagnose VUR because the radiolabelled MAG-3 flows in an anterograde direction from the kidney to the bladder.

D) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic testing is indicated when a secondary cause for VUR, such as neurogenic bladder dysfunction, is suspected. This patient does not have any clinical evidence of neural tube defects (e.g., a lipoma or a tuft of hair near the sacrum), imperforate anus, spinal cord injury, or central nervous system disorders to suggest neurogenic bladder dysfunction. A different test is indicated to first diagnose VUR before assessment for secondary causes of VUR can be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with UTIs, a DMSA scan (static renal scintigraphy) is indicated if any of the following are present to assess the severity of renal cortical scarring: renal parenchymal abnormalities on ultrasonography, increased serum creatinine, breakthrough UTI, or severe VUR (grade III–V). This patient has neither parenchymal abnormalities nor an increased creatinine concentration and did not develop the UTI while on continuous antibiotic prophylaxis. A different test that can diagnose and assess the severity of VUR must first be performed.

F) CORRECT:

Further workup to rule out VUR is indicated for this patient with a history of a previously confirmed UTI and ultrasonographic evidence of hydronephrosis. Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) is the diagnostic procedure of choice to diagnose and assess the severity of VUR after empirical antibiotic therapy is initiated and active infection subsides. Early diagnosis and management of VUR are important to prevent renal failure secondary to renal scarring resulting from recurrent infections. Mild to moderate VUR is managed with continuous antibiotic prophylaxis, behavioral modification (e.g., timed voiding), and regular surveillance, whereas patients with severe VUR should undergo surgical or cystoscopic repair of the vesicoureteric junction.

VCUG may be performed when the prescribed antimicrobial regimen for the UTI has been completed or after the patient is asymptomatic. Studies show no improvement in the rates of detection or the severity of VUR between early (< 7 days after UTI detection) and late VCUG.
Image Description:

Voiding cystourethrogram (AP view)

Bilateral vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) has resulted in dilatation of the ureters and pelvicalyceal systems. The right ureter is tortuous and moderately dilated, with blunting of calyceal fornices (example indicated by arrow) but preserved papillary impressions (green line; Grade 4 VUR). The left ureter is markedly dilated with loss of the fornices and papillary impressions (Grade 5 VUR).

B: bladder

G) INCORRECT:

A CT scan is often used to diagnose urinary calculi among adults. A CT scan is not typically used for diagnosing pathologies associated with VUR (e.g., posterior urethral valves), which are more common causes of hydronephrosis in children than ureteric obstruction by calculi. Additionally, CT scans should be avoided in children because of their significant radiation exposure. A CT scan may be performed if evidence of a perinephric abscess or xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is seen on ultrasonography.
questions.hint: In children aged between 2 and 24 months, a test to identify vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is indicated if any of the following are present: a previously confirmed urinary tract infection (UTI), slow response to antibiotic therapy (> 48 hours), poor urine flow, flank or suprapubic mass, organisms other than Escherichia coli on urine culture, increased creatinine levels, ultrasonographic evidence of hydronephrosis, ureteric dilation, or renal scarring.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of high-grade fever and crying while passing urine. Four months ago, she was treated for a febrile urinary tract infection with cefixime. There is no family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F) and pulse is 123/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase; urinalysis shows WBCs. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli sensitive to cefixime. A voiding cystourethrogram is shown. Without treatment, which of the following is this patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

VUR is not associated with the development of renal cell carcinoma. Von Hippel‑Lindau syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition, is associated with renal cell carcinoma in younger patients, but this patient has no family history of tumors associated with this disease (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, hemangioma), nor would it explain this patient's recurring UTI or findings on voiding cystourethrogram.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with VUR are at increased risk for renal scarring, which is thought to arise from the combination of retrograde flow of urine into the kidneys and increased rates of pyelonephritis. Although VUR and renal scarring have a clear link, the mechanism by which scarring develops is still being investigated. Scarring may be reduced with prophylactic antibiotics, which prevent infections, and surgical correction for those with high-grade vesicoureteral reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with VUR are at increased risk of developing hydronephrosis, not ureter stenosis, due to elevated ureter pressures from the reflux.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital malformations of the female reproductive tract (e.g., bicornuate uterus, Müllerian agenesis) can result in infertility, which can be diagnosed with hysterosalpingography. Although at first glance hysterosalpingography may resemble a VCU (both procedures inject contrast dye into a tubular structure and take serial x-rays of the lower abdomen), a VCU does not delineate the reproductive structures. Instead, it visualizes the urinary tract and can diagnose VUR, which is not associated with infertility.

E) INCORRECT:

VUR is not associated with the development of nephrotic syndrome. Instead, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease (∼ 90% of all cases), the trigger for which is unknown in most cases.

F) INCORRECT:

Smoking is the major risk factor for transitional cell bladder carcinoma, which usually manifests as hematuria in older adults. VUR is not associated with the development of transitional cell bladder cancer. However, transitional cell bladder carcinoma and VUR could result in the dissemination of malignant cells to the upper urinary tract.
questions.hint: This is the patient's second febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) and the voiding cystourethrogram (VCU) shows vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) on the right side.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis. A voiding cystourethrography shows retrograde flow of contrast into the ureters during micturition. Histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Diffuse interstitial infiltration with T lymphocytes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse interstitial infiltration with T lymphocytes can be seen in tubulointerstitial nephritis, which is most commonly caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs (e.g., NSAIDs). It typically presents with fever, hematuria, flank pain, and eosinophiluria (acute tubulointerstitial nephritis), or low-grade proteinuria and progressive CKD (chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis).

B) INCORRECT:

Glomerular crescents, macrophages, and monocytes are common kidney biopsy findings in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), which presents as nephritic syndrome and acute renal failure.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

C) INCORRECT:

Matrix expansion with mesangial proliferation secondary to IgA-based immune complex deposition is a characteristic finding in patients with IgA nephropathy, which typically presents as episodes of hematuria associated with upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal tract infections.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

D) CORRECT:

Cortical thinning with tubular atrophy is seen in patients with hydronephrosis. Chronic retrograde urine flow increases pressure within the nephron lumen and subsequently compresses adjacent blood vessels. Decreased blood flow through these vessels results in decreased renal perfusion and eventually ischemic tubular atrophy, and thinning of the renal cortex and medulla. Serum analysis in this patient will most likely show elevated serum creatinine levels, as both kidneys are affected.
Image Description:

On the left, there is a normal kidney with no obstruction to urinary outflow. Grade I hydronephrosis involves a dilation of the renal pelvis. In grade II, renal calyces are also dilated. Grade III leads to a flattening of papillae. In grade IV, the kidney is completely atrophied.

E) INCORRECT:

Prominent glomerular capillary loops due to thickening of the glomerular basement membrane are seen in membranous nephropathy, which typically occurs among adults and presents as nephrotic syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with bilateral hydronephrosis and recurrent urinary tract infections secondary to vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States reports a 3-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and low-grade fever. He was born preterm and has a history of urinary tract infections that started at age 6 and occurred, on average, one to two times per year.
On examination, his blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his temperature is 37.9°C. Other than mild suprapubic tenderness to palpation, his physical examination is unremarkable.
His urine dipstick shows 2+ leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, and 1+ protein.
Given this patient’s history, which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely underlying cause of his recurrent urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder diverticulum is usually asymptomatic, but patients may present with difficulty voiding and uncomplicated urinary tract infections.

B) CORRECT:

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), the most common identifiable cause of urinary tract infections in young children, occurs when urine passes from the bladder into the upper urinary tract due to incompetence of the ureterovesical junction during bladder contraction. VUR occurs more often in girls, but any child with a urinary tract infection should be evaluated. Risk factors for VUR include a family history of genitourinary tract abnormalities. VUR is associated with pyelonephritis, renal scarring, and secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Early evaluation with voiding cystourethrogram and urology referral for surgical management is warranted.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of childhood-onset recurrent urinary tract infections in a young man is vesicoureteral reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical organisms such as Ureaplasma, Chlamydia, and Mycoplasma are sexually transmitted and can cause recurrent urinary tract infections in young adults, but they do not typically cause recurrent childhood urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic granulomatous disease suffer from recurrent bouts of infection because of the diminished capacity of the immune system. The characteristic infections include pneumonia, abscesses, bacteremia, and suppurative arthritis, but not urinary tract infections in isolation.

E) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic patients with immunoglobulin A deficiency have a history significant for recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, and gastrointestinal tract infections.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman reports dysuria, dark urine, and nausea for the past 3 days. She reports having recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) throughout childhood and early adulthood but did not regularly see a provider during that time. She has no other known health problems.
Her temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure are within normal limits. A urinalysis shows pyuria, hematuria, and proteinuria.
In addition to prescribing appropriate antibiotic therapy for a UTI, you order a kidney ultrasound, given the recurrence of infections. The ultrasound reveals kidneys that are fused in the lower poles (although the most inferior part of the kidneys was poorly visualized), consistent with a horseshoe kidney.
What is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for possible findings associated with the horseshoe kidney?

choices.text: Voiding cystourethrogram to evaluate for vesicoureteral reflux
Kidney biopsy to evaluate for causes of proteinuria
24-hour urine collection to evaluate for risk factors for kidney stones
Magnetic resonance angiography of the brain to evaluate for berry aneurysm
CT of the abdomen to evaluate for renal cysts

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) has a known association with horseshoe kidney, and patients with VUR are at increased risk for recurrent symptomatic urinary tract infections (UTIs). The diagnosis of VUR may be suggested by the presence of hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound, but ultrasound is not a sensitive test for VUR. Diagnosis requires a voiding cystourethrogram.

Key learning point: Horseshoe kidney is an anatomic abnormality that involves abnormal migration and fusion of the kidneys during development, potentially resulting in frequent urinary tract infections, vesicoureteral reflux, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, nephrolithiasis, urogenital cancers, proteinuria, and end-stage kidney disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Horseshoe kidney can cause proteinuria, and urinary protein loss should be quantified after the patient’s UTI resolves. However, there is no indication for kidney biopsy at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with horseshoe kidney are at increased risk for kidney stones; however, there is no indication to perform a 24-hour urine collection to identify kidney-stone risk factors in a patient who does not have nephrolithiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Berry aneurysms are associated with polycystic kidney disease but not with horseshoe kidney.

E) INCORRECT:

Horseshoe kidneys are sometimes not fully visualized on ultrasound. Cross-sectional imaging, such as CT of the abdomen, allows the entirety of the kidneys to be visualized but is not necessary in this case, as the diagnosis of horseshoe kidneys has already been made on ultrasound. Furthermore, although horseshoe kidneys are associated with increased risk for urogenital cancer, screening for the presence of complex renal cysts (which might suggest renal-cell carcinoma) is not indicated in this patient, who is young and has no signs of malignancy or concerning lesions on the part of the kidneys visualized on ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 13-month-old boy is evaluated for care following treatment for a second febrile urinary tract infection (UTI). He was born full-term by vaginal delivery after an uncomplicated pregnancy and normal prenatal ultrasounds. At 4 months of age, he was diagnosed with a febrile UTI and had an unremarkable kidney ultrasound. He has been well without recurrence of infection until now. Two days ago, oral cefixime was initiated in the emergency department for a UTI caused by Escherichia coli. A kidney ultrasound was unremarkable.
On examination, he is afebrile, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 84/38 mm Hg. He is uncircumcised and has a benign abdominal examination.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Observe the child for further urinary tract infections
Recommend and arrange for an elective circumcision
Prescribe prophylactic amoxicillin, to be initiated the day after the current antibiotic course is complete
Schedule nuclear scanning with technetium-labeled dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA scan)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although repeating a renal ultrasound after a second UTI is reasonable, current data suggest that renal ultrasounds have low yield for identifying VUR and are insufficient as a solo imaging modality.

B) INCORRECT:

Although parents may consider an elective circumcision, it is not routinely recommended as part of the initial management in this setting without further investigation.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of prophylactic antibiotics in this clinical setting is controversial and is currently under further investigation. No statistically significant benefit has been demonstrated for children aged 2 to 24 months who do not have reflux or who have grade I-IV reflux. Prophylactic antibiotics are not currently advised without additional evaluation but may be prescribed at the clinician’s discretion.

D) CORRECT:

A child who develops a febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) at <24 months of age should undergo renal and bladder ultrasonography (RBUS). If the child has another febrile UTI, a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is indicated to evaluate for the presence of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Some clinicians recommend a VCUG after the first febrile UTI, because the incidence of scarring increases with subsequent UTIs. A VCUG should also be considered after first UTI in children with an atypical causative pathogen, a complex clinical course, known renal scarring, or a family history of VUR.

Key learning point: The most appropriate evaluation for a child younger than 24 months who has recurrent febrile urinary tract infections and a normal renal ultrasound is to perform a voiding cystourethrogram.

E) INCORRECT:

Although nuclear scanning with technetium-labeled dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA scan) has greater sensitivity for detecting acute pyelonephritis than renal ultrasound or VCUG, it is not recommended as a first-line study to assess for VUR.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents for follow-up of grade III vesicoureteral reflux that was initially diagnosed in infancy. The diagnosis was made on voiding cystourethrogram after he had a febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) and a screening renal and bladder ultrasound (RBUS) revealed hydronephrosis. Since then, he has been taking antibiotic prophylaxis, and the degree of hydronephrosis evident on RBUS has remained stable. Other than a second febrile UTI 18 months ago, he has had no recurrent infections.
Today, he appears well with normal vital signs and a normal creatinine level.
In addition to recurrent UTIs, what is the most likely potential long-term complication of this patient’s vesicoureteral reflux with hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hydronephrosis has a variety of congenital causes, including vesicoureteral reflux (VUR; as in this case), urethral hypoplasia/atresia, ureteropelvic junction stenosis, ureterovesical junction obstruction, and posterior urethral valves. VUR is diagnosed using voiding cystourethrography (VCUG), which this patient underwent after he had a febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) in infancy and a screening renal and bladder ultrasound (RBUS) revealed hydronephrosis. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends screening RBUS for children who have a first febrile UTI before 24 months of age. If the RBUS reveals hydronephrosis or other findings to suggest high-grade VUR or obstructive uropathy, a VCUG should be performed. VCUG may also be considered after a second febrile UTI, even in the presence of a normal RBUS.

The severity of VUR when assessed by VCUG is graded on a scale of I to V, depending on the degree of retrograde filling and dilation of the renal collecting system. Grade I VUR indicates reflux into part of the ureter, grade III indicates reflux into the ureter and collecting system with mild dilation, and grade V indicates massive reflux with gross dilation, tortuosity of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, and loss of the papillary impressions in most calyces. Lower-grade VUR (I-II) tends to resolve spontaneously within 2 to 3 years, whereas higher-grade VUR (III-V) is more likely to persist.

Children with VUR are at increased risk for recurrent febrile UTIs, pyelonephritis, and renal scarring. Notably, the role UTI plays in renal scarring remains controversial, as renal lesions occur in as many as 30% of children with prenatal VUR before their first UTI. Renal scars in febrile UTI may also occur in patients without VUR. Although most professional societies recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for children with VUR, they acknowledge the lack of definitive evidence. Surgical treatment is often considered for patients with grade IV or V VUR.

Key learning point: The most common long-term complication of vesicoureteral reflux with hydronephrosis is renal scarring.

B) INCORRECT:

Although some conditions (e.g., neurogenic bladder) are characterized by both hydronephrosis and urinary incontinence, VUR in isolation does not increase the risk for urinary incontinence.

C) INCORRECT:

End-stage kidney disease is certainly a risk for patients with high-grade VUR and subsequent extensive renal scarring, but this is unusual in patients with mild or treated VUR.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperkalemia would be expected only in advanced chronic kidney disease, which can occur as a complication of long-standing VUR with recurrent UTIs, renal scarring, or both.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperparathyroidism would be expected only in advanced chronic kidney disease, which can occur as a complication of long-standing VUR with recurrent UTIs, renal scarring, or both.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy who recently immigrated to the United States reports a 3-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and low-grade fever. He was born preterm and has a history of urinary tract infections that started at age 2 and have occurred, on average, one to two times per year.
On examination, his blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his temperature is 37.9°C. Other than mild suprapubic tenderness to palpation, his physical examination is unremarkable.
His urine dipstick shows 2+ leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, and 1+ protein.
Given this patient’s history, which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely underlying cause of his recurrent urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder diverticula are usually asymptomatic, but patients may present with difficulty voiding and uncomplicated UTIs. These may also be related to voiding dysfunction and may require VCUG to detect them as they are not always visible on bladder ultrasound.

B) CORRECT:

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), the most common identifiable cause of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in young children, occurs when urine passes from the bladder into the upper urinary tract due to incompetence of the ureterovesical junction during bladder contraction. VUR occurs more often in girls than boys, but any child with a UTI should be evaluated. Risk factors for VUR include a family history of genitourinary tract abnormalities. VUR is associated with pyelonephritis, renal scarring, and secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and can be a cause of end-stage renal disease. Recommendations from specialty groups vary, but nearly all agree that any child with a UTI before age 2 years should undergo a renal ultrasound. Many experts also recommend a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), which is used to detect VUR. VCUG should be considered in any child with recurrent UTIs, regardless of age. Children who develop UTIs after toilet training may develop voiding dysfunction, which can also lead to infections and renal scarring over time. Those with high-grade VUR should be referred to urology for possible surgical management.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in an adolescent without previous workup is vesicoureteral reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic patients with immunoglobulin A deficiency have a history significant for recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, and gastrointestinal tract infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic granulomatous disease suffer from recurrent bouts of infection because of the diminished capacity of the immune system. The characteristic infections include pneumonia, abscesses, bacteremia, and suppurative arthritis, but not UTIs in isolation.

E) INCORRECT:

Atypical organisms such as Ureaplasma, Chlamydia, and Mycoplasma are sexually transmitted and can cause recurrent UTIs in young adults, but they do not typically cause recurrent childhood UTIs and pyelonephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) has resulted in dilatation of the ureters and pelvicalyceal systems. The right ureter is tortuous and moderately dilated, with blunting of calyceal fornices (example indicated by arrow) but preserved papillary impressions (green line; Grade 4 VUR). The left ureter is markedly dilated with loss of the fornices and papillary impressions (Grade 5 VUR).

A CT scan is often used to diagnose urinary calculi among adults. Hyperparathyroidism would be expected only in advanced chronic kidney disease, which can occur as a complication of long-standing VUR with recurrent UTIs, renal scarring, or both.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States reports a 3-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and low-grade fever. He was born preterm and has a history of urinary tract infections that started at age 6 and occurred, on average, one to two times per year. Other than mild suprapubic tenderness to palpation, his physical examination is unremarkable. His urine dipstick shows 2+ leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, and 1+ protein. Given this patient’s history, which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely underlying cause of his recurrent urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder diverticulum is usually asymptomatic, but patients may present with difficulty voiding and uncomplicated urinary tract infections.

B) CORRECT:

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), the most common identifiable cause of urinary tract infections in young children, occurs when urine passes from the bladder into the upper urinary tract due to incompetence of the ureterovesical junction during bladder contraction. VUR occurs more often in girls, but any child with a urinary tract infection should be evaluated. Risk factors for VUR include a family history of genitourinary tract abnormalities. VUR is associated with pyelonephritis, renal scarring, and secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Early evaluation with voiding cystourethrogram and urology referral for surgical management is warranted.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of childhood-onset recurrent urinary tract infections in a young man is vesicoureteral reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical organisms such as Ureaplasma, Chlamydia, and Mycoplasma are sexually transmitted and can cause recurrent urinary tract infections in young adults, but they do not typically cause recurrent childhood urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic granulomatous disease suffer from recurrent bouts of infection because of the diminished capacity of the immune system. The characteristic infections include pneumonia, abscesses, bacteremia, and suppurative arthritis, but not urinary tract infections in isolation.

E) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic patients with immunoglobulin A deficiency have a history significant for recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, and gastrointestinal tract infections.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the office because of a 1-day history of high-grade fever and crying while passing urine. Four months ago, she was treated for a febrile urinary tract infection with cefixime. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F) and pulse is 123/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase; urinalysis shows WBCs. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli sensitive to cefixime. A voiding cystourethrogram shows vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Without treatment, which of the following is this patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

VUR is not associated with the development of renal cell carcinoma. Von Hippel‑Lindau syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition, is associated with renal cell carcinoma in younger patients, but this patient has no family history of tumors associated with this disease (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, hemangioma), nor would it explain this patient's recurring UTI or findings on voiding cystourethrogram.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with VUR are at increased risk for renal scarring. Although VUR and renal scarring have a clear link, the mechanism by which scarring develops is still being investigated. Scarring may be reduced with prophylactic antibiotics, which prevent infections, and surgical correction for those with high-grade vesicoureteral reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with VUR are at increased risk of developing hydronephrosis, not ureter stenosis, due to elevated ureter pressures from the reflux.

D) INCORRECT:

VUR is not associated with the development of nephrotic syndrome. Instead, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease (∼ 90% of all cases), the trigger for which is unknown in most cases.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking is the major risk factor for transitional cell bladder carcinoma, which usually manifests as hematuria in older adults. VUR is not associated with the development of transitional cell bladder cancer. However, transitional cell bladder carcinoma and VUR could result in the dissemination of malignant cells to the upper urinary tract.
questions.hint: This complication of vesicoureteral reflux is thought to arise from the combination of retrograde flow of urine into the kidneys and increased rates of pyelonephritis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the Pediatric Clinic with a six-month history of fever, flank pain, and dysuria. He has had three documented urinary tract infections requiring antibiotic treatment. His growth and development are appropriate for his age. The parents report normal bowel and bladder function. On examination, he is afebrile with no neurological deficits. Renal ultrasound shows mild bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis without signs of anatomical obstruction. A recent urine culture grew Escherichia coli sensitive to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Creatinine
44 μmol/L
27 - 62 μmol/L


Renal ultrasound: Mild bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis without signs of anatomical obstruction
Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vesicoureteral reflux is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and renal pelvis, predisposing children to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) with bacteria such as Escherichia coli. The clinical presentation of recurrent UTIs with fever, flank pain, and dysuria suggests a predisposition to ascending infections due to this retrograde flow. The renal ultrasound findings of mild bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis, without anatomical obstruction, support a diagnosis of reflux. Persistent exposure to infected urine can lead to renal parenchymal injury, highlighting the importance of early diagnosis and intervention. A voiding cystourethrogram can confirm the presence of reflux.

Key learning point: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children and is typically diagnosed with a voiding cysto-urethrogram (VCUG).

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) can cause UTIs in males due to obstruction, leading to stasis and recurrent infections. However, PUV typically presents in infancy with severe obstructive findings, such as a thickened bladder and pronounced hydroureteronephrosis. The renal ultrasound shows only mild bilateral dilation without obstruction, and the child has normal bladder function and growth, making PUV unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic bladder typically presents with abnormal voiding patterns, altered bowel habits, or neurological deficits. This child has normal bladder and bowel function and no neurological impairment. Ultrasound findings in neurogenic bladder often include a trabeculated bladder or significant post-void residual urine, which are absent here. The lack of neurological or bladder symptoms makes neurogenic bladder unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction presents with hydronephrosis due to narrowing at the junction of the renal pelvis and ureter, often with unilateral dilation. The ultrasound shows mild bilateral dilation without anatomical obstruction, which is inconsistent with UPJ obstruction. Recurrent UTIs suggest a different pathophysiological mechanism rather than a structural blockage.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy in your clinic for follow-up of grade III vesicoureteral reflux, initially diagnosed in infancy after a febrile urinary tract infection (UTI). The diagnosis was made by voiding cystourethrogram, and a screening renal and bladder ultrasound (RBUS) at that time showed hydronephrosis. He has been on antibiotic prophylaxis since diagnosis, and the degree of hydronephrosis on RBUS has remained stable. He had one additional febrile UTI 18 months ago but has had no further infections. Today, his vital signs and creatinine level are normal. In addition to recurrent UTIs, which one of the following is the most likely potential long-term complication of his vesicoureteral reflux with hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although some conditions (e.g., neurogenic bladder) are characterized by both hydronephrosis and urinary incontinence, VUR in isolation does not increase the risk for urinary incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperkalemia would be expected only in advanced chronic kidney disease, which can occur as a complication of long-standing VUR with recurrent UTIs, renal scarring, or both.

C) INCORRECT:

End-stage kidney disease is certainly a risk for patients with high-grade VUR and subsequent extensive renal scarring, but this is unusual in patients with mild or treated VUR.

D) CORRECT:

Hydronephrosis has a variety of congenital causes, including vesicoureteral reflux (VUR; as in this case), urethral hypoplasia/atresia, ureteropelvic junction stenosis, ureterovesical junction obstruction, and posterior urethral valves. VUR is diagnosed using voiding cystourethrography (VCUG), which this patient underwent after he had a febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) in infancy and a screening renal and bladder ultrasound (RBUS) revealed hydronephrosis. Children with VUR are at increased risk for recurrent febrile UTIs, pyelonephritis, and renal scarring. Notably, the role UTI plays in renal scarring remains controversial, as renal lesions occur in as many as 30% of children with prenatal VUR before their first UTI. Renal scars in febrile UTI may also occur in patients without VUR.

Key learning point: The most common long-term complication of vesicoureteral reflux with hydronephrosis is renal scarring.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperparathyroidism would be expected only in advanced chronic kidney disease, which can occur as a complication of long-standing VUR with recurrent UTIs, renal scarring, or both.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic with a 1-day history of high-grade fever and crying during urination. She was treated with cefixime for a febrile urinary tract infection 4 months ago. Her temperature is 39.2°C and pulse is 123/min. Physical examination is normal. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase, and urinalysis shows WBCs. Urine culture grows Escherichia coli sensitive to cefixime. A voiding cystourethrogram reveals vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Without treatment, which one of the following is this patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

VUR is not associated with the development of nephrotic syndrome. Instead, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease (∼ 90% of all cases), the trigger for which is unknown in most cases.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with VUR are at increased risk for renal scarring. Although VUR and renal scarring have a clear link, the mechanism by which scarring develops is still being investigated. Scarring may be reduced with prophylactic antibiotics, which prevent infections, and surgical correction for those with high-grade vesicoureteral reflux.

Key learning point: Vesicoureteral reflux increases the risk of recurrent urinary tract infections and can lead to renal scarring if not properly managed.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with VUR are at increased risk of developing hydronephrosis, not ureter stenosis, due to elevated ureter pressures from the reflux.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking is the major risk factor for transitional cell bladder carcinoma, which usually manifests as hematuria in older adults. VUR is not associated with the development of transitional cell bladder cancer. However, transitional cell bladder carcinoma and VUR could result in the dissemination of malignant cells to the upper urinary tract.

E) INCORRECT:

VUR is not associated with the development of renal cell carcinoma. Von Hippel‑Lindau syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition, is associated with renal cell carcinoma in younger patients, but this patient has no family history of tumors associated with this disease (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, hemangioma), nor would it explain this patient's recurring UTI or findings on voiding cystourethrogram.
questions.hint: This complication of vesicoureteral reflux is thought to arise from the combination of retrograde flow of urine into the kidneys and increased rates of pyelonephritis.
